1 Saguntum (an ancient town on the E. coast of Spain, on the site of the present Murviedro) was on friendly terms wit-h the Romans, and its siege by Hannibal (219-218 Re.) was the imme- diate cause of the Second Punic War. The horrors of the siege, which lasted nine months, are described in detail by St. Augustine in the De civitate Dei (iii. 20), who was doubtless Dante’s authority. St. Augustino lays great stress 011 the fact that the Saguntinos underwent all these horrors rather than break saith with Rome—- ‘ne Romanis frangerent fidem ’.
